awd_titl_txt: HIV Persistence During Antiretroviral Therapy: Mechanisms, Models, Computation, and Data Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
HIV persists in patients despite effective antiretroviral therapy. HIV latent infection of CD4+ T cells might be a major obstacle to viral eradication and has been extensively investigated. However, some other factors may also contribute to HIV persistence. The goal of this project is to develop new approaches in mathematical modeling and experimental data analysis to address questions of HIV persistence. Although HIV preferentially infects CD4+ T cells, it also infects other cells, such as macrophages. Macrophages are white blood cells that engulf and digest cellular debris and pathogens. During the engulfment of HIV-infected CD4+ T cells, macrophages can also get infected, contributing to viral production and persistence. In addition to the viral infection of CD4+ T cells, HIV can also be transferred directly from infected to uninfected CD4+ T cells. Such cell-to-cell transmission can take place within the same cell types and also in different cell populations such as macrophages. The relative contributions to HIV persistence from these sources remain largely unknown, but such information is crucial for finding a cure or control of HIV infection. Graduate students will be trained in this project.

In this project, mechanism-based mathematical models will be developed, analyzed, and compared with experimental data to study the relative contributions of various sources to HIV persistence during highly active antiretroviral therapy. In the first part, models with macrophages will be developed to analyze the data of macrophage infection with/without CD4+ T cell infection in different mouse models. The relative contributions from CD4+ T cell infection, macrophage infection, and CD4-to-macrophage transmission to HIV persistence will be evaluated. The second part studies whether cell-to-cell transmission can explain viral persistence during antiretroviral therapy and whether it also contributes to multiple HIV infection. The PI shall develop a new cell-to-cell transmission model including infected cells structured continuously according to their activation status. This provides a new cell-to-cell modeling framework to study HIV latency, low viral load persistence, and emergence of viral blips during suppressive therapy. The results obtained from this project will provide quantitative information on the sources contributing to HIV persistence, which can help develop treatment strategies targeting HIV eradication or control.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This grant advanced mathematical modeling and computational methods to tackle complex problems in HIV infection and other health-related challenges. The research resulted in 38 peer-reviewed publications in leading journals across mathematical biology, applied mathematics, and public health. Key highlights include:

1. HIV persistence and dynamics
We developed several mathematical models to explore HIV persistence despite long-term treatment. A model structured around the activation status of infected CD4+ T cells revealed that cell-to-cell transmission and activation-level fluctuations maintain latent reservoirs, complicating eradication efforts (Journal of Mathematical Biology, 2021). Another model demonstrated the dominant role of cell-to-cell transmission in forming multiple infections, influencing viral evolution and drug resistance (Journal of Theoretical Biology, 2021). Incorporating reactive oxygen species (ROS) into HIV dynamics models highlighted how oxidative stress leads to complex dynamics, including bistability, influencing viral rebound and persistence (International Journal of Bifurcation and Chaos, 2021). These findings provide a robust framework for understanding HIV persistence and potential therapeutic strategies.

2. HIV rebound
Using data from humanized mice, we investigated the dynamics of viral rebound after treatment cessation. Our model identified pre-treatment viral loads and latent infection levels as key factors influencing rebound timing. Early and prolonged treatment significantly delayed viral rebound (Journal of Theoretical Biology, 2023). A separate study explored immune impairment, identifying bifurcation phenomena that explain variations in rebound dynamics among patients (SIAM Journal on Applied Dynamical Systems, 2024).

3. Public health and vaccine strategies
We extended the modeling approaches to address public health questions related to HPV, COVID-19, and other infectious diseases. (1) HPV vaccination: A dynamic model evaluated vaccination strategies in heterosexual and MSM populations. The findings identified optimal allocation strategies to maximize vaccine effectiveness and reduce HPV prevalence (Bulletin of Mathematical Biology, 2021; Journal of Theoretical Biology, 2022; Journal of Mathematical Biology, 2022). (2) COVID-19 control: Compartmental models assessed the impact of face mask policies, social distancing, and vaccination strategies on COVID-19 transmission and mortality. These studies provided critical evidence for policymakers on timely and effective intervention strategies. (Journal of Urban Health, 2021; Vaccine, 2021; Bulletin of Mathematical Biology, 2022).

4. Modeling chronic diseases
The methods used in HIV research were applied to other chronic conditions, advancing understanding and treatment optimization. (1) Diabetes progression: A generalized model incorporating hyperinsulinemia and beta-cell dysfunction enabled the study of individualized glucose and insulin dynamics, providing insights into precise interventions to delay or reverse diabetes progression (PLoS Computational Biology, 2023). (2) Thyroid hormone regulation: A unified model analyzed thyroid hormone dynamics in various conditions, offering a quantitative framework for personalized treatment of disorders like Hashimoto’s thyroiditis and Graves’ disease (Journal of Theoretical Biology, 2021).

5. Oncology and immunotherapy
Our research extended to glioblastoma, an aggressive brain cancer. Using optimal control theory, we optimized combination immunotherapy regimens, demonstrating improved survival outcomes in a virtual murine cohort (Journal of Theoretical Biology, 2024).

Broader Impacts

This grant showcases the potential of modeling and computation in addressing global health challenges, advancing scientific knowledge, and training the next generation of STEM researchers.

1. Graduate training
Four PhD students were mentored during the grant period, three of whom are women. All students made substantial progress, producing peer-reviewed publications and receiving prestigious awards, including the Eleanor Ewing Ehrlich Award, NIH CTSI TL1 Training Grant, and Chat Yin Ho Scholarship. Graduates all secured positions as tenure-track faculty, postdoctoral researchers, and industry professionals.

2. Publications and presentations 
The project produced 38 papers in top-tier journals, including  PLoS Computational Biology, Bulletin of Mathematical Biology, Journal of Mathematical Biology, Journal of Theoretical Biology, and AIDS. Findings were disseminated at major conferences, such as the SMB Annual Meeting, Joint Mathematics Meetings, and AMS Sectional Meetings. Invited talks were delivered at institutions worldwide.

3. Outreach activities
Outreach included talks to high school and undergraduate students, introducing mathematical biology and inspiring interest in STEM careers. For example, a presentation at Buchholz High School’s STEM Club engaged students with accessible examples of mathematical modeling in biology.

4. Community and policy impact
The project provided actionable insights into public health policies, including AIDS control, HPV vaccination strategies, COVID-19 interventions, and air quality measures, directly influencing decision-making at various levels. For example, a study published in AIDS examined the impact of attrition on HIV transmission and drug resistance. The findings emphasized that reducing attrition rates among patients already undergoing treatment is as critical as expanding treatment for untreated patients. These results received significant attention from the research community, with researchers from UCLA and Stanford University Medical Schools publishing editorial comments that underscored the importance of this work (AIDS, 2023).
